newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: FOCUS-Bass set to exercise Prague option.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Bass set to exercise Prague option.

text.p: British brewer Bass Plc said on Monday it would probably exercise an option in Prazske Pivovary a.s. at the start of November to give it a majority stake in the Prague-based brewer.

"We have 46 percent in Prazske Pivovary (PP) now and we also have a five percent option exercisable at the beginning of November...I think we'll exercise that option," Mervyn Childs, Bass country manager for the Czech Republic, told Reuters.
PP is one of the top four brewing groups in the Czech Republic, producing some of the country's most popular brands such as Staropramen, Mestan and Branik.
In 1993, Bass took a 34 percent share in PP for nine million pounds and has been gradually increasing it since.
Childs said that Bass had always foreseen a consolidation in the Czech brewing industry with many smaller brewers being swallowed up and three major groups emerging.
In July, Bass took a 20 percent stake in another of the country's top brewing groups, north Moravia-based Radegast a.s..
Childs said Bass was talking to other major shareholders in Radegast -- IPB a.s. which has 34 percent and KIS a.s. which has around 30 percent -- about increasing its stake.
"We've made no secret of saying we're talking to other shareholders in Radegast. We have 20 percent but would like to increase that shareholding," Childs told Reuters.
"I would like to think there has been some movement (on this) by the end of the year."
Childs said that if plans to take a bigger share in Radegast failed, Bass would look elsewhere in the Czech brewing industry to strengthen its position.
He added that his company was sensitive to national pride about beer in the Czech Republic -- the world's biggest per capita consumer of the drink -- and would be discreet in running its operations.
Asked whether Bass would prefer to achieve its objectives within Radegast without taking a high visibility majority stake, Childs replied: "Yes."
The British brewer also has large stakes in two small regional Czech breweries.
